Nowadays, people use this term much more figuratively, like when they describe [31mgalvanizing[0m a political movement or even a sports team into action.

impeach.colored_long: If you impeach a president, you charge him or her with a crime. Congress may vote to impeach a president, but being impeached is only the first step in removing an official from office. [31mImpeach[0m comes from the Latin [31mimpedicare[0m, meaning "catch, entangle." When you met your first love, your parents thought that the relationship was transitory â€” but fifty years later, you're still married!

So, when you add the prefix [31mun-[0m and the suffix [31m-able[0m, the result is an adjective that means "not able to be accused," in other words, beyond doubt or question. If you run for public office and your past is unimpeachable, your opponents will have nothing to use against you in their advertisements.

When someone is unruly, they've thrown the rules out of the window. An unruly person refuses to obey authority, while an unruly piece of hair might refuse to stay inside a clip. And if a cat herder had trouble corralling kittens for a parade, there would be unruly kittens everywhere!

Use the adjective [31mvernal[0m to describe something that occurs in springtime or is related to springtime. You might be familiar with the vernal equinox, which indicates the beginning of spring in the Northern Hemisphere. The word [31mvernal[0m can also be used more broadly to describe something youthful or fresh — springlike.
